Catalysis and Inorganic Chemistry Division CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory Dr. Homi Bhabha Road Pune Maharashtra 411008 India Diols are important class of industrial chemicals. Their synthesis from bio-resources (instead from fossil feedstocks) is sustainable. In this study, we probed active tungsten species on Pt/W/SBA-15 catalysts for selective synthesis of 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PDO) from aqueous glycerol through a liquid-phase hydrodeoxygenation reaction. A synergistic enhancement in glycerol conversion and 1,3-PDO selectivity was observed when both Pt and W were present on the catalyst. A volcano-shape variation followed with a gradual increase in glycerol conversion and 1,3-PDO yield with W-loading (0.25–15 wt%) was observed. Pt dispersion and acidity of the catalyst displayed similar variations with the W-loading confirming their critical role in the reaction. Structure-function relationships inferred that oligomeric WOx with moderate Brönsted acidity (predominant at 1 wt% W-loading) in contact with dispersed Pt are the active species for 1,3-PDO formation and crystalline WO3 with strong Brönsted acidity (prevalent above 4 wt% W-loading) in association with Pt nanoparticles lead to 1-propanol formation. Graphical abstract Oligomeric WOx with moderate Bronsted acidity in contact with dispersed Pt nanoparticles are the active species for 1,3-propanediol formation and crystalline WO3 species results in 1-propanol formation. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Glycerol 1,3-Propanediol Hydrogenolysis Supported Pt-WOx Active sites Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The high demand for shifting to low-carbon footprint technologies and sustainable manufacturing requires novel conversion methods of renewable resources (biomass, for example) to fuels and value-added chemicals [1–3]. The United States Department of Energy identified glycerol as one of the top-twelve renewable platform chemicals [4]. Glycerol is the by-product in oleochemical industry (biodiesel manufacturing). The expanding market of biodiesel enables glycerol to be available in surplus quantity and at an affordable price. Its valorisation is a necessity for the biodiesel industry to be profitable and sustainable [5]. In this regard, catalytic conversion of aqueous glycerol to renewable diols has gained much attention of the scientific society, as diols are precursors to industrial polymers, paints, adhesives and cleaning and personal care products used in our daily life [6]. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of glycerol yields 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO; via 1°-C-O bond hydrogenolysis) and 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PDO, via 2°-C-O bond hydrogenolysis) as primary products. Their further conversion leads to 1-propanol (1-PO) and 2-propanol (2-PO) as secondary products. 1-PO is also formed directly from 3-hydroxypropionaldehyde (3-HPA) intermediate of 1,3-PDO (Scheme 1 ). Designing highly active and selective catalysts is a daunting challenge in catalysis research and the reaction in this study is of no exception. Of the two PDOs, selective formation of 1,3-PDO (a high value diol) is challenging because of (1) the high steric hindrance of the 2°-OH group of glycerol by its two 1°-OH groups making the former less accessible to the active sites of the catalyst and (2) the close values of dehydration activation energy (70.9 kcal/mol for 2°-OH and 73.2 kcal/mol for 1°-OH) and proton affinity (195.4 kcal/mol for 2°-OH and 194.8 kcal/mol for 1°-OH) of the hydroxyl groups making the selective hydrogenolysis highly demanding [7]. Synthesis of 1,3-PDO from bio-glycerol than from fossil-derived chemicals (viz., acrolein – by the Degussa process and ethylene oxide – by the Shell process) is a step-forward toward achieving the global sustainable development goals and zero-carbon emissions mandate. Further, heterogeneous catalytic approach is more favourable to biological fermentation route as the latter demands costly equipment and complicated methodologies to separate 1,3-PDO from the undesired co-products making the overall process more expensive [8]. Supported Pt-WOx and Ir-ReOx are two sets of metal-acid (bifunctional) catalysts that show promising selectivity to 1,3-PDO with the former being more productive and cheaper than the latter [9–11]. Al2O3 [12–16], SiO2 [17,18], zeolites (SAPO-34 and beta) [19–21] and ZrO2 [22–24] are some supports for Pt-WOx. Diol formation proceeds by the dehydration followed by hydrogenation mechanism [25]. While WOx facilitates adsorption and dehydration of glycerol, platinum promotes activation of hydrogen and the hydrogenation step. Synergistic interactions between Pt and WOx render selective hydrolysis of the 2°-C-O bond of glycerol and formation of 1,3-PDO. Aihara et al. [26] demonstrated that a catalyst with 7 wt% WO3 loading (with WO3 monolayer coverage on Al2O3 of about 33%) exhibits highest conversion of glycerol and selectivity to 1,3-PDO. Those catalysts with lower and higher WO3 loading than the optimal loading (7 wt%) provided lower yield of 1,3-PDO. García-Fernández et al. [15,27] related the hydrogenolysis activity (yield of 1,3-PDO) with tungsten surface density (ρW) that controls the kind of tungsten oxide species present on the Pt/WOx/Al2O3 catalyst surface. The importance of the domain size and degree of polymerization of WOx and oxygen defects to anchor and disperse Pt and maximizing Pt-O-W interfaces were also invoked in the reaction [28–31]. In the presence of hydrogen and precious metal, Hδ+-(WO3)n δ− type Brönsted acid sites were reported to form in situ at the reaction conditions which trigger the hydrogenolysis reaction. Lei et al. [32] reported that hydrogen spillover takes place to a greater extent on WOx species having a medium degree of polymerization due to suitable reducibility of those tungsten oxide species. The yield of 1,3-PDO was correlated with the Brönsted acidity of the catalyst [14], but there were also disagreements in this regard [26]. DFT studies on model systems [33] revealed that NH3 adsorption energies of monomeric HWO4/Pt(111) and trimeric HW3O10/Pt(111) were larger than those of dimeric HW2O7/Pt(111). Compared to HWO4/Pt(111), the dimeric HW2O7/Pt(111) could delocalize more negative charge from tungsten to Pt surface and leads to much stronger Brönsted acid sites. All these studies point out that WOx with a medium degree of polymerization is the active tungsten species in selective hydrogenolysis of glycerol. Priya et al. [34] reported that Pt-WO3/SBA-15 with higher loading of WO3 (10 wt%) prepared by sequential impregnation method (using ammonium metatungstate hydrate and chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate as W and Pt sources, respectively) exhibits high conversion (86%) and 1,3-PDO selectivity (42%) in a vapor-phase continuous-flow hydrogenolysis reaction of aqueous glycerol conducted at 210 °C and atmospheric pressure. Later, Fan et al. [35] demonstrated that Pt/W-SBA-15 with low loading of tungsten (W/Si molar ratio as low as 1/640 and Pt = 3 wt%) enables highest selectivity to 1,3-PDO (70.8%) at glycerol conversion of 86.8% in a batch reactor at 150 °C and 40 bar H2 after 30 h of reaction. Na2WO4.2H2O was the tungsten source and it was incorporated into SBA-15 by a direct sol-gel synthesis route. The tungsten species in Pt/W-SBA-15 was identified as isolated Lewis acidic WO4. Synergy and good match between Pt nanoparticles and WO4 species led to in situ formation of WO4-hydride (under hydrogen atmosphere) which functioned as active catalyst site in the reaction [35]. Feng et al. [36] incorporated W and Al (W+Al = 20 wt%) into SBA-15 by a one-step synthesis method and deposited Pt (2 wt%) onto it. This catalyst showed 1,3-PDO selectivity of about 50% and glycerol conversion of 66% at 160 °C and 60 bar H2 after 12 h of reaction. SBA-15 is an interesting silica support. Its high surface area enables controlled dispersion of metal species and its non-reducible behavior imparts minimal influence on the electronic state of supported metal species. Its ordered mesoporous architecture leads to facile diffusion of reactant and product molecules in and out of the mesopores. Mesoporosity has been exploited for several catalytic applications to improve mass transfer. In addition, crystallinity has also been successfully incorporated within mesoporous structures [37–39]. The earlier studies with SBA-15-based catalysts [34,35] revealed that catalysts with both high (10 wt% WO3) and low (W/Si = 1/640) loadings of tungsten show promising conversion of glycerol in the HDO reaction, causing ambiguity on the structure of active W species on SBA-15 dictating for the selective hydrogenolysis reaction. On Al2O3, below 20 wt% loading, WO3 remains within the monolayer coverage. But such is not the case on silica in spite of its high surface area, as silica support promotes metal oxide sintering. Hence, a systematic variation in W-loading on SBA-15 would provide additional information on tungsten oxide species and their reactivity toward glycerol hydrogenolysis. To probe the active tungsten oxide species on Pt/W/SBA-15 catalysts, we varied, in this work, W-loading from 0.25 to 15 wt%. Platinum-loading was kept mostly at 2 wt%. These catalysts were prepared by a sequential impregnation method (first W and then, Pt were loaded onto SBA-15). An interesting variation in catalytic activity and product selectivity with W-loading on Pt/W/SBA-15 was observed for the first time. Structure-function relationships conclude that dispersed Pt nanoparticles in association with WOx species with a medium degree of polymerization (i.e., oligomeric WOx species; prevelant at around 1 wt% of W-loading on SBA-15) impart high selectivity to 1,3-PDO and the Pt nanoparticles in contact with crystalline, monoclinic WO3 species (predominent at W-loadings of above 4 wt%) are selective to 1-PO (over-hydrogenolysis product) formation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 2Pt/SBA-15 SBA-15 was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis method [40] using tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, Sigma-Aldrich) as silica source, poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(propylene glycol)-block-poly(ethylene glycol) (Pluronic P123, EO20PO70EO20, average molecular weight = 5800, Sigma-Aldrich) as template and HCl (Thomas Baker) as pH controlling agent. Then, platinum (2 wt%) was deposited onto it by an impregnation method. In a typical preparation of SBA-15 [41], 4 g of Pluronic P123 tri-block co-polymer was taken in a polypropylene beaker (500 ml) and 30 g of Millipore water and 120 g of aqueous 2 M HCl solution were added to it. The beaker was placed in an oil bath maintained at 40 °C. The contents were stirred for 4 h till the polymer dissolved completely and a clear, transparent solution was obtained. To it, 8.5 g of TEOS was added drop-wise over a period of 1 h and stirring was continued for another 24 h. The gel formed was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (200 ml) and aged at 110 °C for 48 h placing in an oven. The solid formed was filtered, washed several times with Millipore water, dried initially at 25 °C for 12 h and then, at 110 °C (in an oven) for an additional 12 h. The solid was recovered, ground and calcined in air at 650 °C (ramp rate = 2°C/min) for 7 h to get SBA-15. To prepare 2Pt/SBA-15, a known quantity of tetraammineplatinum(II) nitrate (0.0801 g; (NH3)4Pt(NO3)2 – Pt source; Sigma-Aldrich) was dissolved in 100 ml of Millipore water taken in a glass round-bottom flask at 40 °C by stirring for 0.5 h. To it, 2 g of calcined SBA-15 (prepared as above) was added under constant stirring and the slurry was stirred for 24 h at 40 °C. Water in it was removed over a rotary evaporator. Solid formed was dried in an oven at 110°C for 12 h and calcined in air at 400 °C (ramp rate = 2°C/min) for 4 h. Then, the solid was reduced in a flow of hydrogen (120 ml/min) at 350 °C (ramp rate = 5°C/min) for 2.5 h and labelled as 2Pt/SBA-15 (colour: grey; the numerical before the symbol Pt in the molecular formula refers to the nominal weight percentage of Pt). 2.1.2 2Pt/xW/SBA-15 Tungsten (x wt%) loaded samples (xW/SBA-15) were prepared first by the impregnation method. Then, Pt (2 wt%) was deposited subsequently onto them to obtain 2Pt/xW/SBA-15 catalysts. Ammonium metatungstate (AMT; (NH4)6H2W12O40.xH2O; Sigma-Aldrich) was used as W source. In a typical preparation of xW/SBA-15, an appropriate amount of AMT was dissolved in 100 ml of Millipore water taken in a glass round-bottom flask at 70 °C and stirred for 1 h. Then it was cooled down to 40 °C and 2.5 g of calcined SBA-15 was added. It was stirred for 24 h at 40 °C. Water in it was removed over a rotary evaporator. The solid obtained was dried in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h, calcined at 450 °C for 4 h (ramp rate = 2 °C /min) and was labelled as xW/SBA-15 (colour: colourless to pale yellow with increasing W loading; x = 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1, 1.5, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12 and 15). Then, 0.0801 g of tetraammineplatinum(II) nitrate was dissolved in 100 ml of Millipore water taken in a glass round-bottom flask at 40 °C by stirring for 0.5 h. xW/SBA-15 (2 g; prepared as above) was added. The mixture was stirred for 24 h at 40 °C. Water from it was removed over a rotary evaporator. The solid obtained was dried in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h, calcined at 400 °C for 4 h (with a ramp rate of 2 °C/min) and then reduced in hydrogen flow (120 ml/min) at 350 °C for 2.5 h (with 5 °C/min ramp rate). The catalyst, thus prepared was labelled as 2Pt/xW/SBA-15 (colour: dark grey). 2.2 Characterization techniques Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies in the low-angle region (2θ = 0.5–5° with scan step size of 0.025° and step time of 1 s) were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα (λ = 0.15418 nm) radiation source operating at 40 kV and 30 mA. The measurements in the high-angle region (2θ = 10–90° with scan step size of 0.02° and scan speed of 0.6°/min) were performed on a Rigaku Miniflex X-ray diffractometer equipped with a dual goniometer and Cu-Kα radiation source operating at 30 kV and 15 mA. Nitrogen-physisorption experiments were conducted on a Micromeritics 3Flex adsorption analyzer at -196°C on catalyst samples (sample mass ∼ 0.08 g) degassed at 350 °C for 3 h. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller specific surface area (SBET) of the catalyst samples was calculated from fourteen adsorption data points collected in the relative pressure (P/P0) range of 0.05 ≤ P/P0 ≤ 0.3 of the isotherm. The total pore volume, average pore diameter and pore size distribution of the catalyst samples were derived from the desorption branch of the isotherm using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) measurements were performed on a FEI Nova NanoSEM 450 FESEM equipped with a Schottky field emission gun. The sample (0.001–0.005 g) for the analysis was dispersed in iso-propanol (2-PO, 5 ml) and sonicated for 0.5 h at 25 °C. A drop of above-suspension was placed on a silica chip adhered onto a SEM stud by carbon tape. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were collected on a JEM-F200 multi-purpose electron microscope (JEOL Ltd.) fitted with a 200 kV field emission gun. A drop of the sample sonicated as described above was placed on a copper grid (200 mesh, ICON Analytical) and allowed to dry before it was subjected to the HRTEM study. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) studies were carried out on the same instrument which was also equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) microanalysis unit. Fourier transform Raman (FT-Raman) spectra were recorded in the region of 100–1600 cm−1 using a Horiba-Jobin-Yvon LabRAM HR 800 spectrometer. The spectra were acquired using a He-Ne laser (632 nm, 20 mW) with acquisition time of 10 sec. Diffuse reflectance UV-visible (DRUV-vis) spectral measurements were performed on a Shimadzu UV-2700 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere attachment. The spectra were collected in the wavelength region of 200–800 nm. Kubelka-Munk (K.M.) function for infinity thick samples was used to convert reflectance data into equivalent absorption spectrum. BaSO4 was the reference material. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of power catalyst samples were recorded at 25 °C on a Bruker Biospin A 300 spectrometer operating at X-band frequency (υ = 9.7925 GHz) and 100 kHz field modulation. The spectra reported are the average of 10 scans performed with receiver gain of 1000, field amplitude of 15 G, time constant of 20.48 msec and conversion time of 40 msec. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on a Thermo Fisher Scientific Instrument, UK (Model: K-Alpha+) equipment using Al-Kα anode (1486.6 eV) in a transmission lens mode and multi-channel plate (MCP) detector. The XPS lines were referenced to C1s appeared at 284.8 eV and the spectra were deconvoluted using XPSPEAK41 software employing Shirley background. A powder sample was drop-casted on a silicon wafer which was mounted on a standard stainless steel plate by means of a conductive carbon tape. This was then fixed to a sample holder mechanism and placed in the load lock chamber under vacuum. As the desired vacuum (1.2 × 10−8 mbar) reached, the sample holder was transferred to the analysis chamber (2 × 10−9 mbar) for further analysis. The CO pulse chemisorption studies were carried out on a BEL CAT II Instrument (Microtrac BEL, Japan). Prior to CO chemisorption, the sample (about 0.1 g) was degassed (with He purge gas at a flow rate of 50 ml/min) at 120 °C for 0.5 h and cooled to 50 °C. Then, the sample was reduced using 5 vol% H2 in He at a flow rate of 50 ml/min from 50 to 350 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C/min and continued the reduction at 350 °C for 1.5 h, followed by lowering of the temperature to 50 °C in same gas atmosphere and then, purged with He gas (50 ml/min) for 0.5 h. Subsequently the CO pulses were given at 50 °C using 4.97 vol% CO (in He) and the CO uptake was measured. Acidity of the catalyst samples was determined by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) technique using a Micromeritics (USA) Autochem (model 2920) equipment. The measurement procedure involved activation of the reduced catalyst sample in He-flow (30 ml/min) at 500 ºC for 2 h, followed by cooling to 80 ºC and adsorbing NH3 from a stream of NH3 in He (5 vol%), removing the physically adsorbed NH3 species by desorbing in He-flow at 100 ºC for 1 h and finally performing the NH3-TPD measurement by rising temperature of the catalyst in a programmed manner up to 700 ºC with a heating rate of 10 ºC/min. Ammonia desorption peaks were assigned and quantified using a pre-generated gas calibration file. The calibration was conducted injecting known volumes of NH3-He gas mixture at similar conditions. The types of acid sites were determined by diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transformation (DRIFT) spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine. These studies were performed on a Bruker Tensor-27 FT-IR instrument in conjunction with Harrick high vacuum cell in praying mantis reaction chamber. Reduced catalyst samples were out-gassed at 400 °C for 4 h and then cooled to 30 °C under dynamic vacuum. The sample was exposed to pyridine vapours. The difference spectra were obtained by subtracting the spectrum of the catalyst from that of the pyridine-adsorbed sample. 2.3 Reaction procedure and product analysis Hydrogenolysis of glycerol was conducted in a 100 ml stainless steel batch reactor. In a typical reaction, 0.75 g of glycerol (Sigma-Aldrich) and 24.25 g of Millipore water were taken in the reactor. 0.625 g of catalyst was added to it. The reactor was sealed, purged with nitrogen (to let out air present inside the reactor) and pressurized with hydrogen to 50 bar. Temperature of the reactor was raised to 190 °C and the reaction was conducted for 12 h while stirring at a speed of 600 revolutions per minute (rpm). Then, the reactor was cooled down to 25 °C. Gas was slowly vented out and the left out reaction mixture was collected. The catalyst was separated by centrifugation/filtration and the liquid was passed through a MS® Nylon Syringe Filter (diameter = 33 mm and pore size = 0.22 µm) to eliminate any catalyst particles in it. Then, it was analyzed and quantified by 1H NMR spectroscopy (Bruker AV400 spectrometer) using a solvent-suppression pulse sequence (zgpr) method as detailed by us earlier [42]. For cross verification and confirmation of NMR results, a few liquid reaction product samples were analyzed and quantified also by a gas chromatography (GC) system (Agilent 7890B) attached to an inert XL MSD with triple axis detector (Agilent 5975C) and HP-1/DHA GC column (Part No. 19091S-004; length = 102 m, i.d. = 0.25 mm and film thickness = 0.50 μm). GC conditions: Inlet temperature = 250 °C, split ratio = 50:1 and oven temperature program: start at 150 °C (hold for 2 min) – ramp @ 10 °C/min to 250 °C (hold for 4 min) – ramp @ 20 °C/min to 280 °C (hold for 10 min). MS conditions: electron ionization at 70 eV, transfer line temperature = 280 °C, MS source temperature = 230 °C, MS Quad temperature = 150 °C, mass scan range = 10–300 amu and scan rate = 1.29/sec. Catalytic activity tests were conducted also at varying reaction conditions (temperature = 180–210 °C, initial hydrogen pressure = 20–60 bar, reaction time = 3–24 h and glycerol concentration in water = 3–10 wt%). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Structure and textural properties XRD profiles of reduced 2Pt/xW/SBA-15 catalysts were recorded in both low- (2θ = 0.5–5°) and high-angle (2θ = 10–90°) regions. While the low-angle XRD study provided evidence for the mesoporous structure of SBA-15 support, the high-angle XRD study revealed dispersion and crystalline phases of Pt and W species on SBA-15. “Neat” SBA-15, 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 and 2Pt/12W/SBA-15 showed three resolved XRD peaks in the 2θ range of 0.6°–2° that were indexed to (100), (110) and (200) lattice planes of mesoporous silica with 2D hexagonal structure (space group p6mm; Fig. 1(a)) [40]. High intensity of (100) peak and presence of well-resolved (110) and (200) reflections confirmed the mesoporous structure and long-range ordering of SBA-15 material. A marginal shift in peaks position to higher 2θ values (from 0.99, 1.65 and 1.87° for SBA-15 to 1.03, 1.67 and 1.91° for 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 and 2Pt/12W/SBA-15) inferred reduction in pore size due to deposition of Pt and W species on the pores of SBA-15. Also some reduction in the intensity of (100) peak was observed for metal-loaded SBA-15 samples due to partial blockage of pores by the metal species. The inter-planar spacing (d(100)) and unit cell parameter (a = 2d(100)/√3) values (8.9 nm and 10.2 nm, respectively for SBA-15 and 8.5 nm and 9.9 nm, respectively for 2Pt/12W/SBA-15) determined from the XRD peak position of (100) reflection agree well with the values reported for such materials [40,41]. The XRD profiles of reduced 2Pt/SBA-15 and 2Pt/xW/SBA-15 in the high-angle region are presented in Fig. 1(b). 2Pt/SBA-15 and 2Pt/0.25W/SBA-15 showed a broad peak at around 22.8° and a weak peak at 39.7°. The former is corresponded to amorphous silica forming the pore walls of SBA-15 and the latter to the diffraction from the (111) plane of metallic Pt [34–36]. The weak intensity of Pt peak signifies that platinum is mostly dispersed with crystallite size below the X-ray detection limit (∼5 nm). 2Pt/xW/SBA-15 samples with W-loading between 0.5 and 2 wt% showed only the XRD peak of amorphous SiO2 at 22.8° (Supplementary material; Fig. S1(a)) and those samples with W-loading of 4–12 wt% showed additionally peaks at 23.2, 23.5, 23.8, 26.6, 28.8, 33.5, 34.0, 41.6 and 50.1°, whose intensity increased with increasing W content in the samples (Supplementary material; Fig. S1(b)). They are assigned to diffractions from (002), (020), (200), (120), (-112), (022), (202), (222) and (400) planes, respectively of crystalline, monoclinic WO3 (JCPDS card no. 043-1035) [42,43]. The weak peak (at 2θ = 39.7°) due to Pt(111) present in 2Pt/SBA-15 and to some extent in 2Pt/0.25W/SBA-15 is nearly absent in 2Pt/xW/SBA-15 samples with x = 0.5–12 wt% inferring that the crystallite size of Pt in those catalysts was reduced due to the presence of tungsten in close contact with it [31,35]. Absence of WO3 peaks for the samples with low W-loading suggests that tungsten in those samples is highly dispersed. It may be noted that Pt/W-SBA-15 catalysts with W/Si molar ratio of 1/80 also did not show the presence of crystalline WO3 phase in its composition [35]. Tungsten in those catalysts was present as isolated WO4 species. Our study reveals that the crystalline WO3 phase on SBA-15 evolves at above a W-loading of 4 wt% and below that tungsten is in isolated WO4 or oligomeric or polymeric tungsten oxide (WOx) structures. The 2D hexagonal uniform-size pore structure, long-range mesopore ordering and one-dimensional pore channel arrangement of SBA-15 materials were ascertained from HRTEM images (Supplementary material; Fig. S2). The beautifully curved pores of SBA-15 testified the long-range ordering in these silica materials [44]. Tungsten was uniformly distributed. Metallic Pt particles were highly dispersed within the pores of SBA-15 (Fig. 2 ). Agglomerated Pt particles were almost absent. HAADF-STEM images and elemental mapping of 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 (Supplementary material; Fig. S3) provided evidence for the uniform distribution and close proximity of Pt and W species on the surface of SBA-15. For each sample, about 150 platinum particles were considered in plotting particle size distribution curves and in calculating the average particle size value. For the catalysts with low W-loading (< 2 wt%), the Pt particles were in the range of 1–10 nm, and for the catalysts with high W-loading (> 4 wt%), a few Pt particles with size of about 22 nm were also detected (Supplementary material; Fig. S4). From the HRTEM images, the statistical average particle size of Pt was determined to be 4.0, 3.4, 5.6 and 6.4 nm for 2Pt/0.5W/SBA-15, 2Pt/0.75W/SBA-15, 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 and 2Pt/4W/SBA-15, respectively. It may be noted that the particles with size above the X-ray detection limit (>5 nm) were 10–15% only. Thus, their corresponding peaks in XRD were very weak and not detected. FE-SEM images demonstrated that SBA-15 materials in this study contained spherical particles (1–2.5 μm) and rope-like domains with relatively uniform dimension (of about 1 μm) which were aggregated into network-interconnected structures [45,46]. Both these structural morphologies in turn comprised of long-range 2D ordered pores that were holding the Pt and W particles (Supplementary material; Fig. S5). All these catalysts showed type IV nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms with H1 hysteresis loop (Supplementary material; Fig. S6). The capillary condensation (a sharp increase in the adsorption) occurred at a relative pressure (p/p0) of about 0.76 and confirmed highly ordered mesoporous structure of the materials. The narrow pore size distribution validated the uniformity of the mesopores and substantiated the conclusions from the HRTEM study. When tungsten was also present a remarkable decreased in specific surface area (SBET) from 788 m2/g (for 2Pt/SBA-15) to 639 m2/g (for 2Pt/1W/SBA-15), 585 m2/g (for 2Pt/6W/SBA-16) and 569 m2/g (for 2Pt/12W/SBA-15) was found. Total pore volume decreased from 1.46 cc/g (for 2Pt/SBA-15) to 1.25 cc/g (for 2Pt/1W/SBA-15), 1.11 cc/g (for 2Pt/6W/SBA-15) and 1.10 cc/g (for 2Pt/12W/SBA-15). Conversely, the average pore size increased from 6.0 nm (for 2Pt/SBA-15) to 6.4 nm (for 2Pt/1W/SBA-15), 6.3 nm (for 2Pt/6W/SBA-15) and 6.5 nm (for 2Pt/12/SBA-15). These observations infer that both Pt and W are uniformly distributed within the pores of SBA-15. A part of tungsten occupied the micropores and resulted in apparant increase in the pore diameter values for 2Pt/xW/SBA-15 catalysts compared to 2Pt/SBA-15 [36]. From the unit cell parameter (a; obtained from the XRD study) and average pore size values (obtained from the N2-physisorption study), we estimated the pore wall thickness (a – pore diameter) of 2Pt/12W/SBA-15, which amounted to be 3.4 nm. All these textural values are well within the data known for SBA-15 [40]. CO-chemisorption is an important characterization tool to estimate the surface exposed metal atoms. The volume of CO chemisorbed on 12W/SBA-15 was nearly zero (-0.0656 cc/g-STP) inferring that silica support and tungsten species do not interfere in the determination of the crystallite size of Pt and the number of surface exposed Pt atoms. Specific surface area (APt), percentage dispersion (%D) and average crystallite size of Pt for 2Pt/xW/SBA-15 catalysts were determined from the volume of CO chemisorbed assuming a stoichiometric CO/Pt ratio of one [34,36]. The APt and %D values of Pt increased with tungsten loading up to about 0.75 wt% and then decreased steeply up to 4 wt%. Thereafter these values showed again an upward trend up to about 8 wt% loading of tungsten. Pt crystallite size showed a similar behaviour but a reverse trend (Fig. 3 and Supplementary material; Table S1). The catalyst with 0.75 wt% of W had the smallest crystallite size (1.8 nm) and largest surface area (153 m2/g) and dispersion (62%) of Pt (Fig. 3). 2Pt/12W/SBA-15 had metal surface area, dispersion and crystallite size of 26 m2/g, 10% and 10.9 nm, respectively. These studies conclude that the loading amount of tungsten influences the average crystallite size of Pt nanoparticles in the catalyst. 3.1.2 Spectral properties – molecular electronic structure FT-Raman is a powerful spectroscopic tool to unravel the molecular structure of metal oxides [47–49]. “Neat” SBA-15 showed no prominent Raman features in the spectral region of 100–1500 cm−1. 2Pt/SBA-15 showed weak bands at 485 and 978 cm−1. In contrast, 2Pt/xW/SBA-15 with low W-loading (x = 0.25–2 wt%) showed characteristic Raman bands at 970, 606 and 496 cm−1 due to isolated WO4 and oligomeric WOx species (Fig. 4 ) [47,48]. The high dispersion and low concentration of tungsten oxides on SBA-15 explain the low intensity of these tungsten oxide bands. The catalysts with high W-loading (x = 4–12 wt%) showed additional Raman bands at 800, 705, 326, 261 and 128 cm−1 corresponding to bulk, crystalline, monoclinic WO3 species [49] (Supplementary material; Fig. S7). It also showed a band at 977 cm−1 due to polytungstate (polymeric WOx) species. The bands at 800 and 705 cm−1 are attributed to W-O-W stretching vibrations and the bands at 326 and 261 cm−1 are corresponded to O-W-O bending vibrations [50]. The sharp band at 128 cm−1 is due to framework vibrations. The weak band at 977 cm−1 had nearly the same intensity for all the catalysts having high W content. It is attributed to the symmetric stretching mode of terminal W=O bonds in hydrated polytungstate clusters interacting with the support [51–53]. This band corresponding to terminal W=O stretching vibration appears normally at 1019 cm−1. But its shift to lower energy in the present catalysts suggests interaction of W=O groups with the surface water molecules [54]. Raman scattering cross sections for crystalline WO3 are much greater than those of surface polytungstate and WO4 species and thus, the crystalline WO3 bands dominate the spectrum and limit the detection of WO4 and polytungstate species even when the latter are the most abundant surface species [49]. While the exact quantification of different tungsten oxide species could be difficult, the FT-Raman spectroscopy study revealed that with increasing W-loading, the tungsten oxide speciation changes from WO4 (characteristic FT-Raman band at 970 cm−1) to polytungstate (FT-Raman band at 977 cm−1) and then, to bulk tungsten oxide (WO3; FT- Raman band at 800 cm−1). Unlike FT-Raman, the FT-IR study of these catalysts provided little information on the tungsten oxide speciation as the prominent bands of SBA-15 matrix (Si-O and Si-O-Si) dominated the bands of the WO3 species. DRUV-vis spectroscopy provided further evidence for the molecular structure of tungsten oxides on SBA-15. As expected, no absorption band was detected for “neat” SBA-15. SBA-15 with lower loading of tungsten (xW/SBA-15; x = 0.25–2) showed two ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT; O2p → W5d) bands at 210 and 260 nm confirming the presence of distorted isolated WO4 and penta- or hexa-coordinated oligomeric/polytungstate (WOx) species, respectively (Fig. 5 (a)) [55]. These bands were detected also for Pt/W-SBA-15 catalysts with low amount of W prepared using NaWO4 as tungsten precursor [35]. Thus, the nature of tungsten species at lower loading of tungsten is nearly the same (monomeric WO4 and oligomeric/polymeric WOx species) irrespective of its precursor (NaWO4 or AMT) used in the catalyst preparation. But then, the relative concentration of these species may change depending on the tungsten source used. The ratio of the intensities of these bands at 210 and 260 nm (I210/I260) was 1.3 for 1 wt% W on SBA-15 and it decreased to 1.1 and 0.6 for 4 and 12 wt% W loaded samples (Supplementary material; Fig. S8). At above 4 wt% of tungsten loading, an additional LMCT band at 365 nm was detected which is corresponded to crystalline WO3 species (Fig. 5(a)) [34–36]. Intensity of this band increased with increasing W-loading (Supplementary material; Fig. S9). Absorption edge energy (Eg) value was calculated from the absorbance data of allowed transitions of tungsten oxides. It was found to be 3.73 eV for 1W/SBA-15 and 3.52 eV for 12W/SBA-15. Barton et al. [49] reported such shifts in Eg to lower energies with increasing WO3 concentration on ZrO2 and corresponded to growth in the WOx domain size by formation of corner- and edge-shared WOx octahedra at higher WOx surface densities. Ross-Medgaarden and Wachs [48] reported that the monolayer coverage of tungsten oxide on ZrO2 (SBET = 60 m2/g) and Al2O3 (SBET ∼ 200 m2/g) happens at a W surface density of 4.5 W atoms/nm2. However, on SiO2 (SBET ∼ 330 m2/g), the monolayer surface coverage is not achievable due to agglomeration/sintering of tungsten oxide species on account of weak metal-support interactions. Maximum dispersion that can happen before the crystalline WO3 formation is 0.5 W atoms/nm2. Considering W-loading amount per g-catalyst and SBET values, we determined the W-surface density of 2Pt/1W/SBA-15, 2Pt/6W/SBA-15 and 2Pt/12W/SBA-15 catalysts, which were found to be 0.06, 0.37 and 0.76 W-atoms/nm2, respectively. Thus the data suggest that the catalyst samples with low W-loading (< 2 wt%) contain isolated WO4 and oligomeric WOx species and those with high W-loading (> 4 wt%) contain more amount of polytungstate and crystalline WO3 species. The LMCT band at 365 nm for samples with W-loading greater than 4 wt% agrees with the above conclusion on tungsten oxide speciation. Reduced catalyst samples (2Pt/xW/SBA-15) showed a broad absorption background in the entire spectral region (200–800 nm) on which the tungsten oxide bands appeared as overlapping features (Fig. 5(b)). The background signal corresponds to Pt in metallic state. Reduced catalyst samples with high W-loading showed an additional band at 510 nm, whose intensity increased with increasing W-loading. It is known that in the presence of Pt, a part of tungsten oxide reduces from +6 to +5 oxidation state. The visible band at 510 nm is corresponded to the d-d transition arising from reduced WOx species. This species is possibly located at the periphery of Pt and WO3 species. The presence of reduced tungsten species in catalysts with higher W-loading was confirmed also by EPR and X-ray photoelectron (XP) spectroscopy techniques. EPR is a highly sensitive tool to detect paramagnetic species [56,57]. Catalysts with low W-loading were EPR-silent. But the catalysts with high W-loading (2Pt/10W/SBA-15 and 2Pt/12W/SBA-15) were EPR-active and showed weak axial-type EPR spectrum (Supplementary material; Fig. S10) with signals at g⊥ = 1.915 and g|| = 1.999 corresponding to W5+ species (5d1 electronic configuration; S = ½) in a tetragonally elongated octahedral geometry [58,59]. Intensity of these signals was higher in 2Pt/12W/SBA-15 than in 2Pt/10W/SBA-15 confirming their origin from crystalline tungsten oxide. Because of the low concentration of W5+ and low abundance of non-zero nuclear spin tungsten isotope (183W: 14.31%, nuclear spin (I) = ½), the hyperfine feature of tungsten were not visible. EPR-silence of low W-loaded samples and EPR-active behaviour of high W-loaded samples point out that isolated WO4 and oligomeric WOx species are hard to reduce, while crystalline WO3 can be easily reduced. XPS provided critical information on the oxidation state of Pt and W species on SBA-15. Representative XPS spectra of 2Pt/2W/SBA-15 from the Pt 4f core level and 2Pt/4W/SBA-15 and 2Pt/12W/SBA-15 from the W 4f core level are depicted in Fig. 6 . The Pt 4f lines appeared in the B.E. region of 69–79 eV and those of W 4f appeared in region of 34–39 eV. The spectra were deconvoluted and the spectral lines were assigned (Supplementary material; Table S2). In all the catalysts, Pt was present in zero and +2 oxidation states, with the former being more abundant than the latter. For the catalysts with low W-loading (< 4 wt%), tungsten was present in +6 oxidation state and for the catalysts with high W-loading (> 4 wt%), tungsten was present in +5 and +6 oxidation states, with the latter being more predominant than the former. This result agrees with the EPR study and infers that W-species in the catalysts with lower W-loading were harder to reduce than those present in the catalysts with higher W-loading. The position of XPS lines (4f7/2 and 4f5/2) of Pt/W/SBA-15 catalysts varied with the W-loading as shown in Fig. 7 . This variation is similar to that observed for the CO-chemisorption data (Fig. 3). B.E. values increased with increasing W-loading up to about 1 wt% and decreased later with further increase in the W-loading to about 4 wt%. There onwards the B.E. values showed again a rising trend. Thus, W loading amount influences the crystallite size of Pt (CO-chemisorption), tungsten speciation (DRUV-vis and FT-Raman) and the electronic structure (XPS). No linear relationship was found between the crystallite size and B.E. values of Pt inferring that other factors including tungsten speciation and acidity would also affect the XPS line positions. Thus, there exists an electronic connect between Pt and tungsten species. Pt-WOx behaves like an electron donor-acceptor pair. At the interface, tungsten oxide accepts electron from metallic Pt in contact with it. Those tungsten ions reduce from +6 to +5 state and Pt oxidizes from zero to +2 state. At higher W-loadings (> 4 wt%), Pt is in greater contact with tungsten and leads to higher amount of W5+ species (as confirmed by EPR and XPS). At lower W-loadings, even if a small portion of tungsten was present in +5 oxidation state it would not have been detected due to its lower intensity than the tungsten species with +6 oxidation state. On the top of this, the overall intensity of W 4f line was much lower than that of the Pt 4f line for the catalysts with lower W-loadings. Thus, one cannot completely rule out the presence W5+ species even in those catalysts with lower W-loading just because those species were not detected in the XPS study. For the catalysts with 0.25–0.75 wt% W, the W-concentrations were below our XPS detection limit. 3.1.3 Acidic properties The acidic properties of reduced Pt-WOx catalysts were determined by NH3-TPD and DRIFT spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine. The NH3-TPD profiles (Fig. 8 , left panel) were deconvoluted into three peaks centred at 120, 165 and 320 °C corresponded to weak, medium and strong acid sites, respectively. These peaks appeared for all the Pt/W/SBA-15 catalysts but with increasing W-loading, they shifted to higher temperatures (126, 172 and 343 °C) due to changes in the nature of tungsten species (monomeric, oligomeric/polymeric and crystallite tungsten oxide) present on the catalyst surface. The weak and medium acid sites are of Lewis type and correspond to tungsten with unsaturated coordination sites. The strong acid sites are of Brönsted type and relate to Hδ+-(WO3)n δ− species formed at the interface of Pt and WOx. Overall acidity (Lewis + Brönsted sites defined by the NH3-TPD peaks at 100–450 °C) and in particular, the Brönsted acidity (defined by the TPD peak with maximum at 320–343 °C) increased with increasing W-loading (Fig. 8, left panel). Higher amount of Brönsted acidity (Pt-WOxH sites) for 2Pt/12W/SBA-15 parallels the amount of W5+ species in those catalysts (EPR and XPS). DRIFT spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine (Fig. 8, right panel and Supplementary material, Fig. S11) further substantiated the type of acid sites present in these catalysts. The intense absorption peaks at 1595 and 1445 cm−1 are attributed to pyridine species attached to silanol (Si-OH) groups of SBA-15. The peaks at 1577 and 1485 cm−1 are due to pyridine coordinated to weak Lewis acid sites and those at 1615 and 1457 cm−1 are assigned to pyridine attached to strong Lewis acid sites (surface tungsten sites with unsaturated coordination). The weak peak at 1545 cm−1 evidences the presence of Brönsted acid sites (Pt-WOxH sites) [60,61]. IR peaks corresponding to pyridine attached to Si-OH groups dominated the peaks of Lewis and Brönsted acid sites originating from the tungsten oxide species. The DRIFT spectra of adsorbed pyridine were also recorded as a function of temperature (Supplementary material, Fig. S11) and it was found that the intensity of pyridine peaks associated with Lewis acid sites have almost disappeared at about 200 °C. The weak peak at 1545 cm−1 corresponding to Brönsted acid sites was visible even at 200 °C, inferring that this acid site is the one participates in the HDO reaction of glycerol. 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 Control experiments In general, 1,3-PDO, 1,2-PDO, 1-PO and 2-PO were the products of the liquid-phase hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of glycerol in aqueous medium over 2Pt/xW/SBA-15 catalysts (Scheme 1). Reduced 1W/SBA-15 and 12W/SBA-15 (without Pt) showed poor catalytic activity (glycerol conversion = 6.4 and 4.7 mol%, respectively; Table 1 , Run Nos. 1 and 2) and yielded 1,2-PDO (1°-C-O hydrogenolysis product with selectivity of 28.5 and 40.1 mol%) along with over-hydrogenolysis products (1-PO and 2-PO with selectivity of 57.1 and 40.1 mol% and 14.3 and 20.0 mol%, respectively). 2Pt/SBA-15 (without W) was also not highly active (glycerol conversion = 9.4 mol%; Table 1, Run No. 3) and yielded 1,3-PDO (2°-C-O hydrogenolysis product with selectivity of 30.0%) along with 1,2-PDO, 1-PO and 2-PO with selectivity of 20.0, 40.0 and 10.0 mol%, respectively. 1,3-PDO/1,2-PDO and 1-PO/1,3-PDO molar ratios over this catalyst were 1.5 and 1.3, respectively. On the contrary, the reduced bifunctional catalysts (2Pt/xW/SBA-15) demonstrated enhanced glycerol conversion (14.0–86.0 mol% depending on the W-loading; Table 1, Run Nos. 4–14) and 1,3-PDO selectivity (24.3–52.0 mol%) due to synergistic interactions between Pt and tungsten oxide species on SBA-15 which were in close proximity (HAADF-STEM) and in electronic contact (XPS and EPR). These special and electronic interactions directed the preferred 2°-C-O bond hydrogenolysis over these Pt-WOx bifunctional catalysts. The yield of 1,3-PDO varied from 5.8 to 24.3 mol% (at 190 °C, 50 bar H2 and 12 h of reaction time). Co-existence of Pt and tungsten was essential for the selective hydrogenolysis of glycerol. 1-PO was the only product formed with 100% selectivity when 1,3-PDO (instead of glycerol) was the substrate,. Catalysts with both low and high W-loadings (2Pt/1W/SBA-15 and 2Pt/12W/SBA-15) showed similar conversions of 1,3-PDO (11.8 and 13.1 mol%, respectively at 8 h of reaction; Supplementary material, Table S3). On the other hand, when 1,2-PDO was used as substrate, both 1-PO and 2-PO formed as products with the former being more selective (76.1–80.3 mol%) than the latter (23.8–20.1 mol%), inferring that 2°-C-O hydrogenolysis is the preferred transformation over these bifunctional catalysts. The catalyst with higher W-loading (2Pt/12W/SBA-15) exhibited two times higher activity (42.0 mol%) than the catalyst with lower W-loading (2Pt/1W/SBA-15; 22.5%; Supplementary material, Table S4). Thus, over-hydrogenolysis reaction is more predominant over the catalysts with higher W-loading. 1-PO formed from both 1,2-PDO and 1,3-PDO. Under similar experimental conditions (reaction temperature = 190 °C, initial H2 pressure = 50 bar and reaction time = 8 h), conversion of different substrates varied in the order: glycerol > 1,2-PDO > 1,3-PDO and infers the importance of vicinal dihydroxy groups for adsorption and activation of substrate molecules. 2Pt/12W/SBA-15 exhibited higher activity than 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 (Fig. 9 ). 3.2.2 Effect of tungsten loading amount Earlier works on Pt-WOx catalysts with Al2O3 [15,26,27,32], SiO2 [33] and ZrO2 [29] supports showed a volcano-shape variation for the HDO activity with WO3-loading or tungsten-surface density (maximum HDO activity at a particular amount of WO3 loading and lower activity below and above that critical WO3 loading was observed). However, while using SBA-15 support in this study, we observed a different type of variation for the HDO activity (Table 1, Fig. 10 , left panel). Tungsten loading on the catalysts was varied from 0.25 to 15 wt%. Glycerol conversion increased from 14.0 mol% (at 0.25 wt% W-loading on SBA-15) to 51.0 mol% (at 1 wt% W-loading) and then, decreased to 19.2 mol% (at 2 wt% W- loading). Thereafter, till 15 wt% of W-loading, a gradual rise in glycerol conversion to 86.0 mol% was observed, inferring that a catalyst with higher W-loading is more active than that with lower W-loading. The behaviour up to 2 wt% W-loading (volcano-shape variation) is similar to that reported for Pt-WOx catalysts supported on Al2O2 and ZrO2 [15,26,27,29]. But, the behaviour above 2 wt% W-loading is different and not reported till date. The variation in product selectivity with W-loading on SBA-15 is shown in Fig. 10, right panel. The selectivity to 1,3-PDO and 1,2-PDO showed a steep increase with increasing W-loading up to 1 wt% and then, decreased gradually. In contrast, the selectivity to 1-PO and 2-PO showed a reverse trend. It decreased with increase in W-loading up to 1 wt% and then, increased gradually with further rise in the W-loading. The catalyst with lower W-loading enabled 1,3-PDO with high selectivity, while the catalyst with higher W-loading resulted 1-PO with high selectivity (Table 1, Run Nos. 7 and 13). Product selectivity should have been the same if the structure of tungsten oxide species on the catalyst was the same at all W-loadings. But spectroscopic investigations (DRUV-vis and FT-Raman) confirmed that with varying W-loading, the structure of tungsten species varies from monomeric WO4 to oligomeric and polytungstate and then, to crystalline WO3. The variations in catalytic activity and product selectivity can, therefore, be related to the variation in tungsten oxide speciation on the catalyst. At low W-loadings (0.25–2 wt%), tungsten is in monomeric WO4 (DRUV-vis band at 210 nm) and oligomeric WOx (band at 260 nm) forms, with the latter being more predominant at around 1 wt% of W-loading. At a W-loading of 2–4 wt%, the polytungstate (WOx) species and at above 4 wt%, crystalline WO3 species are the prevalent tungsten species. All these species can co-exist at different W-loadings but in different proportions. Thus, higher selectivity to 1,3-PDO at a W-loading of 0.5–1 wt% infers that oligomeric WOx are the selective tungsten species for 1,3-PDO formation. Crystalline WO3 leads to over-hydrogenolysis and 1-PO formation. Neither monomeric WO4 (at 0.25 wt% W-loading) nor polytungstate species (at 2–4 wt% W-loading) are highly active/selective HDO catalysts. Based on the selectivity and yield of 1,3-PDO, the bifunctional catalysts with composition of 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 are preferred to 2Pt/12W/SBA-15. The latter are more active but selective to 1-PO. 3.2.3 Influence of reaction parameters The HDO reaction over 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 catalyst was carried at different H2 pressures conditions (20–50 bar). With increasing pressure, glycerol conversion increased from 31.9 to 51.0 mol%. The selectivity and yield of 1,3-PDO increased with H2 pressure up to 40 bar and then showed a marginal decreased at 50 bar (Supplementary material, Table S5 and Fig. S12). Hydrogen is one of the reactants in the HDO reaction. It has a positive effect on the reaction. Increased amount of active hydrogen species formed at high pressure of hydrogen over 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 catalyst is the cause for higher activity and yield of 1,3-PDO at higher hydrogen pressure. In terms of the yield of 1,3-PDO, 40 bar was the optimum hydrogen pressure. Since glycerol conversion was higher at 50 bar, further optimizations were performed at this condition only. Similar observations were reported also for Pt-H4SiW12O40/SiO2 [62] and Pt-HPA/ZrO2 [63] catalysts. But, rate independence of hydrogen was found for Pt/W/beta catalyst [21] due to superior ability of hydrogen to dissociate over the zeolite catalyst leading to sufficient amount of activated hydrogen species during the reaction. With increasing glycerol concentration (from 3 to 10 wt%), conversion of glycerol and yield of 1,3-PDO had decreased (41.3 to 11.8 mol% and 19.5 to 5.5 mol%, respectively) due to increased viscosity of the reaction medium at higher glycerol concentrations [63]. However, the selectivity to 1,3-PDO was little affected irrespective of glycerol concentration perhaps due to the consecutive reactions of diols to mono-alcohols which were unaffected at these conditions (Supplementary material, Table S6 and Fig. S12). Reaction temperature has a favourable effect on glycerol conversion, which increased continuously from 39.4 to 59.9 mol% with increase in reaction temperature from 160 to 200 °C. But the selectivity to 1,3-PDO had decreased from 53.8 to 39.0 mol% due to over-hydrogenolysis and formation of 1-PO (36.8 mol%) at higher temperatures (Supplementary material, Table S7 and Fig. S12). The optimum temperature for the high yield of 1,3-PDO lies at 180 – 190°C. While the selectivity to 1,3-PDO was nearly the same, glycerol conversion and 1,3-PDO yield increased with increasing reaction time from 3 to 30 h (Fig. 11 ). The yield of 1,3-PDO was about the same on 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 and 2Pt/12W/SBA-15 catalyst. But 1-PO formed was higher on the latter than on the former catalyst (Supplementary material, Tables S8, S9 and Fig. S12). The initial rates (0.425 and 0.610 mmolglycerol/h for 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 and 2Pt/12W/SBA-15, respectively) were determined from conversion versus time plots (Fig. 11). The corresponding turnover frequency values (TOF; defined as moles of glycerol converted per mole of exposed Pt (taking account of Pt dispersion in the catalyst) per hour) for 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 and 2Pt/12W/SBA-15 were found to be 13 and 95 h−1, respectively. The TOF values based on 1,3-PDO formed (moles of 1,3-PDO formed per mole of exposed Pt per hour) were 6 and 26 h−1, respectively. In spite of its good catalytic performance, 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 was not stable in reusability studies due to agglomeration of Pt particles (XRD, TEM) and necessitates further work to improve its stability. 3.3 Structure-function relationships and active tungsten species 2Pt/xW/SBA-15 catalysts exhibited enhanced HDO activity (glycerol conversion and 1,3-PDO selectivity) than the individual monometallic catalysts (xW/SBA-15 and 2Pt/SBA-15) (Table 1) establishing the importance of the presence of both Pt and W species in the catalyst and the synergy between them due to their close proximity (HAADF-STEM) and electronic contact (XPS and EPR). W-loading on the catalyst had a marked influence on the catalytic activity and product selectivity (Fig. 10). Structure and spectroscopic characterization studies revealed the presence of different types of tungsten oxide species at varying W-loadings on the catalysts. Monomeric WO4 and oligomeric (moderately polymerized) WOx were the major species at 0.25–2 wt% W-loading. Polymeric WOx were present at 2–4 wt% W-loading and crystalline tungsten oxide (WO3) species were present above 4 wt% W-loading. The variation in catalytic activity and selectivity with W-loading prompts us to propose that catalysts with predominant oligomeric WOx species (at about 1 wt% W-loading) are relatively more selective to 1,3-PDO while those with crystalline WO3 species (at above 4 wt% W-loading) are more active and selective to 1-PO. Both monomeric WO4 (at W-loading below 0.5 wt%) and polytungstate species (at W-loadings of 2–4 wt%) are weakly active and selective to 1,3-PDO. The variations in glycerol conversion and Pt dispersion/surface area with W-loading were similar (Figs. 3 and 10) implying that dispersion of Pt is a critical factor toward high activity of this bifunctional catalyst. These catalysts are acidic and contain Lewis and Brönsted acid sites (Fig. 8). Origin of acidity in these catalysts is due to the tungsten oxide species. Representative structures of surface tungsten oxide with tetra- and penta/hexa-coordination and with Lewis/Brönsted acidity are depicted in Scheme 2 . DRUV-vis (bands at 210 nm for tetra-coordinated WO4 and at 260 and 365 nm for penta/hexa-coordinated WOx species), FT-Raman (peaks at 970 and 977 cm−1 for W=O and W-OH groups and 800 and 705 cm−1 for W-O-W moieties), EPR (signals at g⊥ = 1.915 and g|| = 1.999 for paramagnetic W5+ species) and XPS (lines at 35–38 eV for W in +5 and +6 oxidation states) provide evidence for these tungsten oxide species. Parallel variations were found also for acidity (Supplementary material, Fig. S13) and glycerol conversion (Fig. 10) with W-loading revealing the importance of acidity in the HDO reaction. Too strong acidity (shift in NH3-TPD peak from 320 to 343 °C at higher W-loadings; Fig. 8) leads to over hydrogenolysis. 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 having Brönsted acid sites (Pt-(WOxH)) with moderate acidity (NH3-TPD peak at 320°C) enabled highest selectivity to 1,3-PDO. At optimized reaction conditions, 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 (190°C, 50 bar H2 and 18 h) afforded 1,3-PDO yield of 25.3 mol% (glycerol conversion = 55.8 mol% and 1,3-PDO selectivity = 45.3 mol%) and 2Pt/12W/SBA-15 (190 °C, 50 bar H2 and 12 h) provided 1,3-PDO yield of 24.3 mol% (glycerol conversion = 75.9 mol% and 1,3-PDO selectivity = 32.1 mol%) (Table 1 and Supplementary material, Table S8). Apart from substantiating the works of Priya et al. [34] and Fan et al. [35], these correlations point out that dispersed Pt in contact with oligomeric WOx species with moderate strength Brönsted acidity are the active sites to provide high selectivity to 1,3-PDO and those Pt associated with crystalline WO3 species with strong Brönsted acidity are more active but selective to 1-PO. The high activity of 2Pt/12W/SBA-15 is due to the fact that higher amount of Pt is in contact with the tungsten oxide species than in 2Pt/1W/SBA-15. In fact, by increasing the Pt-loading from 2 to 3 wt% on xPt/1W/SBA-15, we found that the glycerol conversion increases from 41.3 (Table 1, Run No. 7) to 86.2 mol% and 1,3-PDO yield increases from 19.5 to 34.4 mol% at 190 °C, 50 bar H2 and 12 h. 3Pt/1W/SBA-15 at 160 °C, 50 bar H2 and 12 h afforded glycerol conversion of 73.6 mol% and 1,3-PDO yield of 43.1 mol%. Thus, there is scope for these high surface area mesoporous catalysts to improve their performance further, while maintaining the dispersion of Pt and the oligomeric structure of WOx and establishing greater contact/proximity between Pt and active tungsten species. The amount of Pt-loading had little effect on the state of the tungsten species in these catalyst samples. Tungsten species would aggregate into polytungstate and crystalline WO3 at higher calcination temperatures of above 600 °C. In other words, calcination temperature of the catalyst would also dictate the type of tungsten species present on the catalyst surface. Considering this, we employed moderate calcination temperature of 450 °C in our catalyst preparation. Table 2 presents catalytic activity data of selected silica-supported Pt/W catalysts for hydrodeoxygenation of glycerol. Direct comparison of the activity of listed catalysts is difficult as the reaction data available (in Table 2) are at different experimental conditions. However, it can be said that the catalyst of the present study is among the highly performing silica-based HDO catalysts. Synergy and right match between Pt and W-loading is a must for high HDO activity and 1,3-PDO selectivity. Zhou et al. [33] constructed model HWxOy clusters on Pt(111) and estimated NH3 adsorption energy using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The adsorption energy on isolated HWO4/Pt(111), dimeric HW2O7/Pt(111) and linear and angular HW3O10/Pt(111) was estimated to be -93.5, -117.4, -113.2 and -111.4 kJ/mol, respectively. Ammonia adsorption energies of HWO4/Pt(111) and HW3O10/Pt(111) were larger than that of dimeric HW2O7/Pt(111) indicating that the HWxOy cluster with a moderate degree of polymerization (oligomeric species) has the right kind of Brönsted acidity than monomeric and polymeric tungsten oxide species. Our experimental results and the theoretic work of Zhou et al. [33] complement each other and establish the importance of oligomeric WOx species in Pt/W/SBA-15 catalysts for the high selectivity to 1,3-PDO in glycerol hydrodeoxygenation reaction. Fig. 12 depicts a tentative reaction mechanism and Pt-WOx cooperation in 1,3-PDO formation from glycerol over 2Pt/1W/SBA-15 catalysts. Nanoparticles of metallic Pt and oligomeric WOx with W in +6 oxidation state were the species present in the catalyst precursor. At reaction conditions and in hydrogen atmosphere, active Ptδ+-(WO3)nH species are formed which trigger the hydrogenolysis reaction. In the first step, glycerol is activated and 2,3-dihydroxypropoxide is formed by binding 1°-OH group to Brönsted acidic reduced tungsten oxide sites ((WO3)nH). Subsequent to this, dissociative adsorption and spillover of hydrogen at Pt sites resulting in H+ and H− species lead the 1,3-PDO formation via 2-C-O bond scission, 2°-carbocation formation, hydride ion shift and hydrolysis reactions. The cooperation between oligomeric WO3 with moderate acidity and dispersed Pt in its proximity drive the selective formation of 1,3-PDO from glycerol. Such a metal-ligand cooperation is known also in the catalysis over metalloenzymes (activation of hydrogen by Fe-Fe hydrogenase, for example) [66] and organometallic complexes [67]. This cooperation or ligand-controlled selectivity happens by three means: (1) ligand enhances the Lewis acidity/basicity on metal, (2) ligand facilitates formation of high energy (unstable) or low energy (stable) metal oxidation state, and (3) ligand along with metal directly participates in substrate bond making/breaking. All these three pathways lead to ligand-controlled selectivity. The cooperative effect observed in the present study over Pt/xW/SBA-15 catalysts is similar to that happening in metalloenzymes and metal complexes. WOx plays the role of a ligand (and promoter) to Pt influencing the selectivity of the catalyst and facilitating the formation of 1,3-PDO. 4 Conclusion The active tungsten species on mesoporous, bifunctional Pt/W/SBA-15 catalysts for hydrodeoxygenation of aqueous glycerol to 1,3-PDO were probed. A series of 2Pt/xW/SBA-15 catalysts with W-loading ranging from 0.25 to 15 wt% was prepared by sequential impregnation method and characterized. Variation in W-loading led to differences in tungsten oxide speciation present on the catalyst. Isolated tetra-coordinated WO4 and oligomeric WOx species were predominant at W-loadings of 0.25–2 wt%. Polymeric WOx were prevalent at 2–4 wt% W-loading and crystalline WO3 was outstanding at above 4 wt% W-loading. A synergistic enhancement in glycerol conversion and 1,3-PDO selectivity was found when both Pt and W were present in the catalyst. A unique variation (volcano-shape followed with gradual increase) in glycerol conversion and 1,3-PDO yield with W-loading amount was observed. Structure-function relationships established that oligomeric WOx with moderate-strength Brönsted acidity in contact with dispersed Pt are the active species for 1,3-PDO formation, and crystalline WO3 species with strong Brönsted acidity associated with Pt lead to 1-PO. Dispersed metallic Pt nanoparticles facilitate dissociative adsorption of hydrogen and its spillover onto the tungsten oxide species. Close proximity and electronic contact between Pt and W species lead to electron transfer from platinum to tungsten oxide species and generate interfacial W5+ associated with Brönsted acidity (Pt-(WO3H) species) that activate 1°-OH group and promote 2°-C-O hydrogenolysis of glycerol. coredata.dc:description: Diols are important class of industrial chemicals. Their synthesis from bio-resources (instead from fossil feedstocks) is sustainable. In this study, we probed active tungsten species on Pt/W/SBA-15 catalysts for selective synthesis of 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PDO) from aqueous glycerol through a liquid-phase hydrodeoxygenation reaction. A synergistic enhancement in glycerol conversion and 1,3-PDO selectivity was observed when both Pt and W were present on the catalyst. A volcano-shape variation followed with a gradual increase in glycerol conversion and 1,3-PDO yield with W-loading (0.25–15 wt%) was observed. Pt dispersion and acidity of the catalyst displayed similar variations with the W-loading confirming their critical role in the reaction. Structure-function relationships inferred that oligomeric WOx with moderate Brönsted acidity (predominant at 1 wt% W-loading) in contact with dispersed Pt are the active species for 1,3-PDO formation and crystalline WO3 with strong Brönsted acidity (prevalent above 4 wt% W-loading) in association with Pt nanoparticles lead to 1-propanol formation.
coredata.dc:title: Insights into active tungsten species on Pt/W/SBA-15 catalysts for selective hydrodeoxygenation of glycerol to 1,3-propanediol
